body.p:
The understoodsigned state that Lofton Mitchell of this county has been indicted by a Grand Jury of this county for Robbery. We Know Mitchell to have been an ardent and active Union Man from the beginning of the war, and in the Fall of 1862 he enlisted in the 8 Regt of Ky Cavalry then forming at Henderson Ky to which place he went as a refugee and for the purpose of enlisting in said service and served through the term of said Regt and was honorably discharged after having made a gallant and active and enterprising soldier. That after the Regt was mustered out of service, he and a number of his neighbors united for the purpose of protection from Guerilla Bands prowling about and who were particularly vindictive and cruel towards all who had been in the Federal service. While thus engaged a Rebel Col. or Major named Bob Martin made ^a raid^ into the Counties of Trigg, Christian, Muhlenburg and Caldwell counties, and were pursued by the forces of the 3rd Ky Cavalry, Col Murray and driven again across Cumberland river and on their retreat encamped between Cumberland and Tennessee on his return loaded with booty. These Home guards got together and prominent among those were Lofton Mitchell pursued Martin and attacked him in Camp and routed him and near all his booty arms &c
They returned the horses taken from neighbours and turned over the other possessions to Col C. H. Murray at Hopkinsville. These men performed diverse other services to union cause which must not be mentioned. in all of which Mitchell was at all times an active cooperater. In 1864 these men under Capt were organized as State or Capital Guards in Company (B) 3rd Battalion of Capital Guards for six months and served his Term and was honorably discharged on the 12 Feby 1865 by the expiration of the Term at Paducah, by Major M. A Parin commanding their Regt. While in this service Capt Henry E. Luton orders from Parin his Major to go to Canton & Linton on Cumberland River in this county with orders to press horses of Disloyal men to Mount the Regt. Genl Paine then Commadnding at paducah gave them Steam Boat transportation for this trip and under Capt Lutan Lofton Mitchell was acting as an private ^orderly sergeant^ and acting under the orders of his captain the horse of E. Degraffenried was a rebel ^was pressed^ which horse was assigned to Lofton Mitchell to ride while in the service last aforesaid. Now at the present Term of the Trigg circuit court, the Grand Jury composed almost wholly of rebels have indicted said Michell for Robbery in taking and riding the horse under the above circumstances. We know the petit Juries to be composed nearly altogether of Rebels and Believe if the case comes to trial they will if permitted by the court find him guilty.

We know there is in the minds of most
Rebels and Rebel Sympathizers a deep hostility towards all active union men and more especially toward those who lent their services to their country as soldiers to put down the Rebellion. There is a great disposition to oppress and persecute them. We hope you will at once give him a full and free pardon and we will every pray &c

W. A. Bogard formerly of the 8th Ky. Cav
G H Mitchersson of 8th Ky Cavalry
John Martin of 8th Ky cavalry
The foregoing was subscribed and sworn to by W A Bogard G W Mitchersson and Jno Martin before me this 18th day of Sept 1865
J W Nunn J. P. T. C

W. A. Bogard 2d Lieut of Capital Guard
W W Higgins of Capital guard
Thomas W. Rhoades of Ky capital guard
F M Higgins of Capitol Guard
J C Lane Seargeant Co B Capital Guard
John Martin Seargant Co B Capital Guard
The foregoing statement was subscribed and sworn to by M M Higgins Thos M Rhoads F M Higgins and J C Lane before me Given under my hand this 19. Sept 1865
J. W, Nunn J. P. T. C

Trigg Cir Ct
vs
Lofton Mitchell
Wm Bogard
Futrell Foard
Pardon the offense and remit the penalties thereto affixed by law
